questions.text: A 32-year-old traveller who was lost in the desert was found after two days. He says he has not consumed food or water for more than 24 hours. His vitals were normal. Which of the following parts of the kidney must have been the site of maximum water reabsorption in this case?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule is the site of maximum water reabsorption about 67% of the filtered water.

The driving force for water reabsorption is a transtubular osmotic gradient established by reabsorption of solutes.

Based on the ultrastructure proximal tubule is divided into three segments:

  • S1 segment: 1st half of PCT
  • S2 segment: 2nd half of PCT and 1st half of proximal straight tubule
  • S3 segment: 2nd half of proximal straight tubule

questions.text: Regarding the swimming pool sanitation, how much percent of water needs to be replaced every day with freshwater?
questions.solution:
About 15% of the water should be replaced with fresh water every day.

The reason for water replacement is to remove solutes consisting of ammonia, albuminoid, organic, and nitrates derived from the bathers. These solutes have the capacity to reduce the bactericidal activity of chlorine.

Swimming pool sanitation:

  • Bacteriological quality of water has to be close to the drinking standards.
  • Recommended area of minimum of 2.2 m2 per person.
  • The filtering should be continuous such that all the water is re-filtered in less than 6 hours
  • Rapid sand filters must be used.
  • The free residual chlorine level has to be 1 mg/litre (1 ppm)
  • The pH of the water must be 7.4 - 7.8

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient with a known history of rheumatic heart disease, you notice a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex,  radiating to the axilla and back. Which of the following changes in the Murmur would you expect to see if the patient is made to squat from a standing position?

choices.text: Variable change depending on age of patient

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a patient with a known history of rheumatic heart disease, having a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex, radiating to the axilla and back indicates a probable diagnosis of Mitral Regurgitation. 

On squatting from a standing position, systemic vascular resistance, blood pressure, and cardiac size increase. Thus the intensity of murmur would increase

questions.text: A 60-year-old male suffered a stroke a month ago and has since been recumbent. The following findings are seen on his physical examination over the sacrum. Which of the following interventions is not helpful to prevent the occurrence of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a recumbent man with examination findings as shown is representative of pressure ulcers. Massaging of bony prominences is avoided as it contributes to pressure ulcer formation.

Pressure-induced skin and soft tissue injuries are localized areas of damage to the skin and/or underlying tissue usually over a bony prominence. Commonly occurs over the sacrum, calcaneus, ischium, etc.

Prevention of pressure ulcers - 

  • Pressure redistribution - achieved by appropriate use of pressure-reducing devices and surfaces such as air-fluidized beds and proper patient positioning
  • Improve mobility
  • Improving skin perfusion - involves treatment of hypotension, limiting vasoconstrictive agents, improving cardiac contractility, or revascularization for some patients with severe peripheral artery disease
  • Providing skincare to optimize skin temperature, color, turgor, moisture status, and integrity.
  • Correct malnutrition
  • Multilayer foam dressings
  • Bedside pressure mapping

questions.text: A car driver hit his right knee to the dashboard on the sudden application of the brake during a motor vehicle collision. He complains of pain and swelling in the right knee. On examination, there is an excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur. Which is the most likely injured structure?

choices.text: Both Anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments

questions.solution:
The Posterior cruciate ligament is most commonly injured by a direct anterior blow such as dashboard injuries.

The initial symptoms are very similar to an ACL injury like the immediate swelling. On performing the posterior drawer test, there would be excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur. The majority of patients with an isolated PCL injury will return to a high level of function just with appropriate quadriceps rehabilitation and avoid surgical intervention.

Dashboard injury can also lead to:

  • Posterior hip dislocation
  • Acetabular fracture
  • Patellar fracture
  • Fracture of neck of the femur
  • The shaft of femur fracture
  • Posterior cruciate ligament injury

questions.text:
Which of the following diseases cannot be treated by phototherapy?
  1. Psoriasis
  2. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  3. Vitiligo
  4. Dermatomyositis
  5. Dysplastic naevus syndrome
questions.solution:
Phototherapy cannot be used in the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus, dermatomyositis, and dysplastic naevus syndrome. On the contrary, they are absolute contraindications for phototherapy.

Phototherapy is a form of treatment where nonionizing radiations, commonly ultraviolet radiations are used on the skin. It can be in the form of 

1. UVB- Ultraviolet B rays are the rays that have wavelengths between 280 and 320 nm. If all these wavelengths are used it is called a full spectrum. If only 311–313 nm is used, then it is called narrow-band UVB. It has anti‐inflammatory, immunosuppressive, and cytotoxic properties. Use of UVB does not require the wearing of any photoprotective gear. It can be used for thin plaque and macules, and in pregnancy, and in people with liver diseases.

2. UVA-Ultraviolet A are the radiations that have wavelengths between 320 and 400 nm. It is usually used in combination with a psoralen photosensitizer, either orally or topically (PUVA). It acts by cross‐linking of DNA by psoralen photoadducts, inhibition of DNA replication, Langerhans cell depletion, immunosuppressive effects on T‐lymphocyte function and migration, and the restoration of Th17/ regulatory T-cell imbalance in psoriasis. It is used in lesions refractory to UVB, thick plaques, palmoplantar disease, nail disease, etc. 

3. Photopheresis involves the addition of psoralen to the patient’s white blood cells after they have been separated from whole blood ex vivo. The photoactivated white blood cells are then irradiated with UVA and reinfused back into the patient. It is used in the treatment of the erythrodermic stage of cutaneous T‐cell lymphoma, graft‐versus‐host‐disease, etc

Common diseases where phototherapy is used are:

  • Psoriasis
  • Atopic eczema
  • Cutaneous T cell lymphoma
  • Vitiligo
  • Polymorphic light eruption
  • Lichen planus, etc

Absolute contraindications of phototherapy

  • Dysplastic naevus syndrome
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Genetic skin cancer syndromes (xeroderma pigmentosum, Gorlin syndrome)
  • Bloom syndrome, Cockayne syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is increased in a patient under inhalation anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Work of breathing is increased under the effect of General (Inhalational) anesthesia.

Work of breathing is the energy required to carry out inspiration and expiration. Normally only inspiration requires energy, to overcome the elastic recoil of the lung and chest by the diaphragm, whilst expiration is passive. However, under anesthesia, muscle tone is reduced and work of breathing is increased. It can be circumvented by controlled mechanical ventilation.

Other options are decreased under the effect of general anesthesia.

Compliance is the change in volume per unit change in transpulmonary pressure. It is measured in terms of elastic recoil. With reduced diaphragmatic tone, the abdominal contents push the lung cephalad, making it difficult for lung expansion during inhalation. Hence compliance is decreased under anesthesia.

Functional residual capacity or FRC is the volume of air in the lung after quiet expiration. It is greatly affected by sex, body habitus, and posture. It reduces from standing or sitting to supine and even furthermore in the prone position. In the supine position (which is usually the case in inhalation anesthesia), the abdominal contents push the lung upwards, causing a decrease in FRC.

Closing capacity is the minimum lung volume after which the smaller airways start collapsing. The smaller airways lack cartilaginous support and to keep them open, it needs to have air inside it. Thus further reducing the lung volume would cause them to close. It is generally agreed that it decreases in anesthesia.

questions.text: A 45-yr-old man with a history of major depressive disorder presents to the psychotherapist after an episode of depression triggered by the death of his wife. By the end of session, the patient unconsciously starts developing feelings towards the therapist similar to the one which he had for his wife. This is an example for____________
questions.solution:
The above given scenario is an example of transference.

Transference is a situation where the feelings, desires, and expectations of one person are redirected towards another person. It is the process of the patient unconsciously displacing those behavioral patterns and emotional reactions experienced with people from earlier in life (often childhood) onto individuals in his or her current life. In the clinical situation, the displacement is onto the psychiatrist who is often an authority figure or a parent surrogate.

Other options:

  • Parapraxis: When the patient reveals his feelings unconsciously by a slip of tongue, it is known as parapraxis. Freud ascribed parapraxis to unconscious motives.
  • Counter-transference: Happens when the therapists unconsciously displace behavioral and emotional patterns of a significant figure from their earlier life onto the patient. 
  • Catharsis: The expression of ideas, thoughts, and suppressed emotions by the patient which provides a sense of relief. It is also known as ventilation. In catharsis, the patient reveals information voluntarily and consciously whereas, in parapraxis, patient details are revealed unconsciously, by slip of tongue.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the course of the thoracic duct?

choices.text: Drains lymph from the right upper limb
Extends from L4 to the root of the neck
Formed by the fusion of intestinal and two lumbar lymph trunks

questions.solution:
The thoracic duct is formed by the fusion of intestinal and two lumbar lymph trunks.

Course of the thoracic duct:

  • The thoracic duct extends from vertebra L1 or L2 to root of neck. It is formed by the fusion of intestinal and two lumbar lymph trunks to form cisterna chyli.
  • It then passes through the aortic hiatus and enters the posterior mediastinum.
  • In the mediastinum it crosses the midline from right to left at the level of the fifth thoracic vertebra.
  • It then ascends upwards and empties into the venous system at the junction of left subclavian and left internal jugular veins.

The thoracic duct drains lymph from the entire body, except the right part of the head, neck, heart, right upper limb, right lung, and part of the convex surface of the liver.

questions.text: Accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes is treated with recombinant ____________
questions.solution:
Accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes is seen in Pompe disease (type 2 GSD) and is treated with recombinant alpha glucosidase/acid maltase. This is the only glycogen storage disorder with lysosomal accumulation of glycogen.

Pompe' disease: It is due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. The clinical symptoms are hypotonia (floppy infant), hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and chest X-ray image in these patients show cardiomegaly. The affected child usually dies around the age of 2 years due to heart failure.

Other options:

In glucose-6-phosphatase and glycogen phosphorylase deficiency, glycogen accumulates in the cytosol.

Beta glucosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher’s disease, which is a sphingolipidosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Histopathology showed the following appearance. Which of the following is true about this tumour?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Mutation in CDH-1 gene is associated with lobular carcinoma.

Lobular Carcinoma:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Multicentric
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors(50% to 65% of tumors) –Range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. questions.text: True statement regarding the image is -

choices.text: Metaphysis of distal femur is common location
Diaphysis of humerus is most common location

questions.solution:
The image shows lateral radiograph of the tibia demonstrating lesion with poorly marginated edges in diaphysis of the bone. The lamellated periosteal reaction in diaphysis is suggestive of Ewing’s sarcoma which is a highly radiosensitive tumour.

Ewing sarcoma:

  • Is a malignant bone tumor characterized by primitive round cells without obvious differentiation.
  • It accounts for 6% to 10% of primary malignant bone tumors.
  • Ewing sarcoma follows osteosarcoma as the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children.
  • Approximately 80% of affected patients are younger than 20 years. Boys are affected slightly more frequently than girls.
  • Usually, the tumor arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis.
  • Fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis may be seen.
  • Plain radiographs show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins that extends into the surrounding soft tissues.
  • The characteristic periosteal reaction produces layers of reactive bone deposited in an onion-skin fashion.
  • It arises in the medullary cavity. Ewing sarcoma usually invades the cortex, periosteum, and soft tissue.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
